Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Synthesis, Microstructure, and Properties of Novel Magnesium-based Nanoporous Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: This CAREER project aims to acquire fundamental and comprehensive understanding of the relationships among processing, microstructure and properties of magnesium-based nanoporous materials. The specific technical objectives of the research are to synthesize magnesium-based nanoporous materials, characterize their microstructural features using the state-of-the-art tools, experimentally investigate their properties and mechanical behavior and evaluate these behaviors in the light of current theoretical understanding.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: The success of this research will allow full advantage to be taken of nanoporous magnesium for a variety of applications that utilize combinations of mechanical properties, ultralight weight, excellent energy absorption capability, and multifunctionality that accompany the introduction of nanopores into non-porous metals. The research will also advance the underlying understanding of the processing-structure-property relationships in other nanoporous metallic materials. This project will integrate research and education/outreach activities to train undergraduate and graduate students for the workforce, and stimulate the interest and participation of high school students and underrepresented student groups (Hispanic and Women) in science and engineering. The results will be disseminated to other researchers and the general public through a variety of channels such as international journals, technical conferences and the internet. These activities are expected to increase the general public awareness of advanced nanostructured metallic materials and their scientific importance, and to enhance the broader public interest in science, engineering, and the pursuit of technology-oriented careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project involved various research, education and outreach activities. The research results indicated that the synthesized porous magnesium based materials had appealing microstructure and properties. Various materials such as alumina, carbon nanotube, and carbon nanofiber were utilized as reinforcing phase. Some of the important scientific findings are: the increase of ball milling time led to the gradual decrease of the average size of magnesium powders; the powder size range first increased with the increase of ball milling time and then decreased with the further increase of ball milling time; the results for porous magnesium reinforced by carbon nanotubes showed that total specific surface area increases significantly with the increase of overall porosity and the introduction of about 49% porosity increased total specific surface area by 40 times when compared with the material with 0% porosity; for the porous magnesium composites with less than 2% carbon nanofibers, the strengthening mechanism is Orowan strengthening and thermal expansion coefficient mismatch strengthening; for the porous magnesium composites with more than 2% carbon nanofibers, load transfer is the dominating strengthening factor. The establishment of the processing-structure-property relations is expected to promote the practical applications of porous magnesium based lightweight materials in various structural, energy, and bio-devices and components. The findings are disseminated in journal papers. Additionally, the results were presented in the international technical conferences through keynote talks, invited talks, and regular talks. One symposium on “Nanocomposites: Synthesis, Processing, Characterization, and Modeling” was organized in ASME 2015 Applied Mechanics and Materials Conference.

 

The education activities involved a diverse group of students such as domestic and international students; female and male students; graduate and undergraduate students. These students were trained to operate various experimental equipment, analyze and present research data, write scientific papers and thesis/dissertation, and exercise on proposal writing. The graduate students also learned teamwork skills and leadership skills. Both female and male graduate students graduated and acquired their MS and PhD degrees through performing the research of this project. The PI reached out to high school students and middle school students through recruiting high school students as interns in the PI’s group, visiting middle schools and high schools, presenting to the students at their schools, and exhibiting demos to high/middle school students when they visit the university. The high school interns were paired with the university students in the PI’s group to improve teamwork skills and communication skills of both high school students and university students, and leadership skills of university students.


Last Modified: 11/12/2017
Modified by: Qizhen Li
